questions.text: A 10-ft ladder leans against a vertical wall. The top slides down at 1 ft/s when the top is 6 ft above the ground. Find the speed of the bottom sliding **away** from the wall at that instant.
Find the rate of change of the area of the right triangle formed by the wall, ground, and ladder at that instant.
Find the rate of change of the angle \theta between the ladder and the ground then (radians/sec).

answers.text: Let \x be the distance of the bottom from the wall and \y the height of the top. Then \x^2+\y^2=10^2. Differentiate: \2x\,\d x/d t + 2y\,\d y/d t=0. With \y=6, \d y/d t=-1, and \x=\sqrt{100-36}=8, we get \d x/d t = -\dfrac{y}{x} \d y/d t = -\dfrac{6}{8}(-1)=\boxed{\tfrac{3}{4}\,\text{ft/s}}.
Area \A=\tfrac12 x y. Then \d A/d t=\tfrac12\big( x\,\d y/d t + y\,\d x/d t \big)=\tfrac12\big(8(-1)+6(\tfrac34)\big)=\tfrac12(-8+4.5)=-\boxed{1.75\,\text{ft}^2/\text{s}}.

Use \sin\theta= y/10. Differentiate: \cos\theta\, \d\theta/d t = (1/10)\, \d y/d t. At the instant, \cos\theta = x/10 = 8/10 = 0.8 and \d y/d t = -1, so \d\theta/d t = \dfrac{(-1)/10}{0.8} = -\boxed{\tfrac{1}{8}\,\text{rad/s}}.
